name: PowerUp API Documentation
body:
# PowerUp API V1
## Codename "Squirrel"
[PowerUp](https://powerup.io) is a personal analytics tool that turns your achievements and goals into stories. The PowerUp API, documented here, allows you to slice and dice your PowerUp data, and find correlations within. Over time, we'll release tools to help you do this, using this API.

#**NOTE: This API is not yet stable, and this is only a preview. Please don't use it until this warning is removed. Stay tuned!**

# Basic Concepts
PowerUp revolves around a few really basic concepts for representing goals and achievements, Grids, and PowerUps.

## Grids
Grids represent a goal you'd like to achieve. This grid can contain a description, one or many users collaborating together, and PowerUps that represent steps toward the overall goal.

### Data Structure
    {
      "id": String,
      "name": String,
      "about": String,
      "data_types": [
        {
          "data_type": String,
          "name": String
        }
      ],
      "grid_buttons": [ String ],
      "user": User,
      "is_private": Boolean,
      "collaborators": [ User ],
      "powerUps": [ PowerUp ],
      "slug": String,
      "size": Number
    }      

## PowerUps
PowerUps represent individual achievements, steps toward a bigger goal, for example, running 1 mile. These PowerUps contain metadata, which can include any arbitrary stats or info you like. Grids typically include 3 different PowerUp types, which represent different achievements.

### Data Structure
    {  
      id: String,
      position: Number,
      color: String,
      grid: Grid,
      user: User,
      metadata: {
        "grid_data_type_name": Object
      },
      createdAt: String

## Users
Users are people who collaborate on grids. You can see their name, id, and the grids you have in common. You can also see the PowerUps they've earned on the grids you share.

### Data Structure
    {
      id: String,
      name: String,
      grids: [ Grid ],
      power_ups: [ PowerUp ]
    }

# Advanced Queries
Any primitive field type (String, Number, Array, etc.) can be filtered using mongodb's query and projection operators. [See the mongodb reference page for more details.](http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/operator/#query-update-and-projection-operators) Not all of the operators will work in all situations, for example, update operators won't work in list queries.
